trans-unit.source: has its own pair of quotes, which may or may not be bracketing quotes, for example, s(foo)(bar) or s/bar/. A /e will cause the replacement portion to be treated as a full-fledged Perl expression and evaluated right then and there. It is, however, syntax checked at compile-time. A second e modifier will cause the replacement portion to be evaled before being run as a Perl expression.
trans-unit.target: tiene su propio par de citas, que puede o no puede ser horquillado citas, por ejemplo, s(foo)(bar) o s/bar/ . A /e hará que la parte de reemplazo se trate como una expresión Perl completa y se evalúe en ese mismo momento. Sin embargo, se verifica la sintaxis en tiempo de compilación. Un segundo modificador e hará que la parte de reemplazo se eval úe antes de ejecutarse como una expresión de Perl.

A second e modifier will cause the replacement portion to be evaled before being run as a Perl expression.

trans-unit.source: has several functions that can be useful. It has versions of the previous two functions that take strings as inputs -- not single numeric code points: uni_to_native() and native_to_uni() . If you must look at the individual bytes comprising a UTF-8 encoded string, byte_utf8a_to_utf8n() takes as input a string of those bytes encoded for an ASCII platform, and returns the equivalent string in the native platform. For example, byte_utf8a_to_utf8n("\xC2\xA0") returns the byte sequence on the current platform that form the UTF-8 for U+00A0 , since "\xC2\xA0" are the UTF-8 bytes on an ASCII platform for that code point. This function returns "\xC2\xA0" on an ASCII platform, and "\x80\x41" on an EBCDIC 1047 one.
trans-unit.target: tiene varias funciones que pueden ser útiles. Tiene versiones de las dos funciones anteriores que toman cadenas como entradas, no puntos de código numérico individuales: uni_to_native() y native_to_uni() . Si debe mirar los bytes individuales que comprenden una cadena codificada en UTF-8, byte_utf8a_to_utf8n() toma como entrada una cadena de esos bytes codificados para una plataforma ASCII y devuelve la cadena equivalente en la plataforma nativa. Por ejemplo, byte_utf8a_to_utf8n("\xC2\xA0") devuelve la secuencia de bytes en la plataforma actual que forma el UTF-8 para U+00A0 , ya que "\xC2\xA0" son los bytes UTF-8 en una plataforma ASCII para eso punto de código. Esta función devuelve "\xC2\xA0" en una plataforma ASCII y "\x80\x41" en una EBCDIC 1047.

trans-unit.source: has the bit RV2CVOPCV_MARK_EARLY set, then the handling of a GV reference is modified. If a GV was examined and its CV slot was found to be empty, then the gv op has the OPpEARLY_CV flag set. If the op is not optimised away, and the CV slot is later populated with a subroutine having a prototype, that flag eventually triggers the warning "called too early to check prototype".
trans-unit.target: tiene el bit RV2CVOPCV_MARK_EARLY establecido, entonces se modifica el manejo de una referencia GV. Si se examinó una GV y se encontró que su ranura de CV estaba vacía, entonces la OPpEARLY_CV gv tiene activada la bandera OPpEARLY_CV . Si la operación no se optimiza y la ranura de CV se llena más tarde con una subrutina que tiene un prototipo, esa bandera finalmente activa la advertencia "llamado demasiado pronto para verificar el prototipo".

trans-unit.source: has the bit RV2CVOPCV_RETURN_NAME_GV set, then instead of returning a pointer to the subroutine it returns a pointer to the GV giving the most appropriate name for the subroutine in this context. Normally this is just the CvGV of the subroutine, but for an anonymous (CvANON ) subroutine that is referenced through a GV it will be the referencing GV. The resulting GV* is cast to CV* to be returned. A null pointer is returned as usual if there is no statically-determinable subroutine.
trans-unit.target: tiene el bit RV2CVOPCV_RETURN_NAME_GV establecido, entonces, en lugar de devolver un puntero a la subrutina, devuelve un puntero al GV dando el nombre más apropiado para la subrutina en este contexto. Normalmente, este es solo el CvGV de la subrutina, pero para una subrutina anónima ( CvANON ) a la que se hace referencia a través de un GV, será el GV de referencia. El GV* resultante se convierte en CV* para ser devuelto. Un puntero nulo se devuelve como de costumbre si no hay una subrutina determinable estáticamente.

trans-unit.source: have a greater or lesser applicability than that phrase's translation into another language -- for example, strictly speaking, in Arabic, the "your" in "Your query matched..." would take a different form depending on whether the user is male or female; so the Arabic translation "your[feminine] query" is applicable in fewer cases than the corresponding English phrase, which doesn't distinguish the user's gender. trans-unit.source: have locales that work, using them may be worthwhile for certain specific purposes, as long as you keep in mind the gotchas already mentioned. For example, if the collation for your locales works, it runs faster under locales than under Unicode::Collate; and you gain access to such things as the local currency symbol and the names of the months and days of the week. (But to hammer home the point, in v5.16, you get this access without the downsides of locales by using the :not_characters form of the pragma.)

have to return an ARRAY reference, we'll choose a HASH reference to represent our object. A HASH works out well as a generic record type: the {ELEMSIZE} field will store the maximum element size allowed, and the {ARRAY} field will hold the true ARRAY ref. If someone outside the class tries to dereference the object returned (doubtless thinking it an ARRAY ref), they'll blow up. This just goes to show you that you should respect an object's privacy.
trans-unit.target: tenemos que devolver una referencia ARRAY, elegiremos una referencia HASH para representar nuestro objeto. Un HASH funciona bien como un tipo de registro genérico: el campo {ELEMSIZE} almacenará el tamaño máximo de elemento permitido, y el campo {ARRAY} contendrá la verdadera referencia ARRAY. Si alguien fuera de la clase intenta eliminar la referencia del objeto devuelto (sin duda pensando que es una referencia de ARRAY), explotará. Esto solo sirve para demostrarle que debe respetar la privacidad de un objeto.

trans-unit.source: hide bugs in your code since important checks (like correctness of prototypes) is moved from compile time to runtime. In particular, if the prototype you specified on autouse line is wrong, you will not find it out until the corresponding function is executed. This will be very unfortunate for functions which are not always called (note that for such functions autouse ing gives biggest win, for a workaround see below).
trans-unit.target: ocultar errores en su código ya que las comprobaciones importantes (como la corrección de los prototipos) se mueven del tiempo de compilación al tiempo de ejecución. En particular, si el prototipo que especificó en la línea de uso autouse es incorrecto, no lo descubrirá hasta que se ejecute la función correspondiente. Esto será muy desafortunado para las funciones que no siempre se llaman (tenga en cuenta que, para tales funciones, el uso autouse proporciona la mayor ganancia, para una solución alternativa, consulte a continuación).

in m/PATTERN/. If "'" is used as the delimiter, no interpolation is done. Returns a Perl value which may be used instead of the corresponding /STRING/msixpodualn expression. The returned value is a normalized version of the original pattern. It magically differs from a string containing the same characters: ref(qr/x/) returns "Regexp"; however, dereferencing it is not well defined (you currently get the normalized version of the original pattern, but this may change).
trans-unit.target: en m/PATTERN/ . Si se utiliza "'" como delimitador, no se realiza ninguna interpolación. Devuelve un valor Perl que puede usarse en lugar de la expresión /STRING/msixpodualn correspondiente . El valor devuelto es una versión normalizada del patrón original. Se diferencia mágicamente de una cadena que contiene los mismos caracteres: ref(qr/x/) devuelve "Regexp"; sin embargo, la eliminación de referencias no está bien definida (actualmente obtiene la versión normalizada del patrón original, pero esto puede cambiar).

trans-unit.source: in m/PATTERN/. If "'" is used as the delimiter, no variable interpolation is done. in that the subroutine is only called once. However, it's not exactly like this latter code either, because the chained comparison doesn't actually involve any temporary variable (named or otherwise): there is no assignment. This doesn't make much difference where the expression is a call to an ordinary subroutine, but matters more with an lvalue subroutine, or if the argument expression yields some unusual kind of scalar by other means. For example, if the argument expression yields a tied scalar, then the expression is evaluated to produce that scalar at most once, but the value of that scalar may be fetched up to twice, once for each comparison in which it is actually used.

trans-unit.source: in the world as \w . For example, your locale might not think that LATIN SMALL LETTER ETH is a letter (unless you happen to speak Icelandic), but Unicode does. Similarly, all the characters that are decimal digits somewhere in the world will match \d ; this is hundreds, not 10, possible matches. And some of those digits look like some of the 10 ASCII digits, but mean a different number, so a human could easily think a number is a different quantity than it really is. For example, BENGALI DIGIT FOUR (U+09EA) looks very much like an ASCII DIGIT EIGHT (U+0038). And, \d+ , may match strings of digits that are a mixture from different writing systems, creating a security issue. num() in Unicode::UCD can be used to sort this out. Or the /a modifier can be used to force \d to match just the ASCII 0 through 9.
trans-unit.target: en el mundo como \w . Por ejemplo, es posible que su localidad no piense que LATIN SMALL LETTER ETH es una letra (a menos que hable islandés), pero Unicode sí. De manera similar, todos los caracteres que son dígitos decimales en algún lugar del mundo coincidirán con \d ; esto es cientos, no 10, posibles coincidencias. Y algunos de esos dígitos parecen algunos de los 10 dígitos ASCII, pero significan un número diferente, por lo que un humano podría pensar fácilmente que un número es una cantidad diferente de lo que realmente es. Por ejemplo, BENGALI DIGIT FOUR (U + 09EA) se parece mucho a un ASCII DIGIT EIGHT (U + 0038). Y, \d+ , puede coincidir con cadenas de dígitos que son una mezcla de diferentes sistemas de escritura, creando un problema de seguridad.num () en Unicode :: UCD se puede utilizar para solucionar esto. O el modificador /a se puede usar para forzar a \d para que coincida solo con ASCII 0 a 9.

trans-unit.source: in the world as \w. For example, your locale might not think that LATIN SMALL LETTER ETH is a letter (unless you happen to speak Icelandic), but Unicode does. Similarly, all the characters that are decimal digits somewhere in the world will match \d; this is hundreds, not 10, possible matches. And some of those digits look like some of the 10 ASCII digits, but mean a different number, so a human could easily think a number is a different quantity than it really is. For example, BENGALI DIGIT FOUR (U+09EA) looks very much like an ASCII DIGIT EIGHT (U+0038), and LEPCHA DIGIT SIX (U+1C46) looks very much like an ASCII DIGIT FIVE (U+0035). And, \d+, may match strings of digits that are a mixture from different writing systems, creating a security issue. A fraudulent website, for example, could display the price of something using U+1C46, and it would appear to the user that something cost 500 units, but it really costs 600. A browser that enforced script runs ("Script Runs") would prevent that fraudulent display. "num()" in Unicode::UCD can also be used to sort this out. Or the /a modifier can be used to force \d to match just the ASCII 0 through 9.
